messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME(s)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-04-29T18:51:49Z
## Message ID: 20160429-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Several CMEs have been detected in the past 24 hours in the available STEREO and SOHO coronagraph imagery. CMEs originate from the vicinity of the active region 12535 currently located at N07E08. The CMEs were fairly slow and have very faint signatures in the coronagraph imagery making them difficult to analyze accurately.  Although the CMEs appear slow, S-type CMEs (<500 km/s), due to their proximity to a coronal hole and corresponding corotating interaction region (CIR), there is a possibility for moderate geomagnetic activity around 2016-05-01 to 2016-05-02. The elevation in activity can be caused by possibly merged CIR and CME structures impacting the EarthÂ’s magnetosphere.

Activity IDs: 2016-04-28T02:12:00-CME-001, 2016-04-28T06:36:00-CME-001, 2016-04-28T07:24:00-CME-001

## Notes: 


[1] http://iswawiki.gsfc.nasa.gov/wiki/index.php/Glossary/Heliospheric_Earth_Equatorial_coordinates

SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for April 20, 2016 - April 26, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-04-28T01:49:32Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-04-20T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-04-26T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160428-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low to moderate levels during this reporting period.  There were 2 C-type CMEs (see details below).   A CME arrival was detected at STEREO A magnetic field and plasma data around 2016-04-27T09:00Z corresponding to the halo CME that started on 2016-04-25T05:12Z (see notification 20160425-AL-001).  

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic period of 2016-04-23T21:00Z-24:00Z.  This slight increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival detected by ACE at L1 of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2016-04-22.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 


Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.


##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2016-04-24T04:24Z     ~510            C               115/24                40                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
2016-04-25T05:12Z     ~695            C              -165/5                 45                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-04-27T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-05-03T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  There are several active regions present in the solar disk, especially an active region on the far side seen in the northwest of the STEREO A EUVI images, that are capable of producing solar flares and coronal mass ejections.  Geomagnetic activity is also expected to increase due to the arrival of a solar sector boundary crossing around 2016-04-29.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME update
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-04-25T15:44:16Z
## Message ID: 20160425-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Update on CME with ID 2016-04-24T04:24:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20160424-AL-001).  Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CME has little or no impact on Earth or other locations.


Updated CME parameters are (event C-type):

Start time of the event: 2016-04-24T04:24Z.

Estimated speed: ~510 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 40 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 115/24 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates (see [1] in Notes).

Activity ID: 2016-04-24T04:24:00-CME-001


Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME(s): 2016-04-24T04:24:00-CME-001):

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CMEs (STEREO A, Spitzer)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-04-25T15:26:28Z
## Message ID: 20160425-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Multiple CMEs have been detected as follows:
1: S-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2016-04-24T23:36Z.

Estimated speed: ~276 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 45 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -163/7 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates (see [1] in Notes).

Activity ID: 2016-04-24T23:36:00-CME-001

2: C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2016-04-25T05:12Z.

Estimated speed: ~695 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 45 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -165/5 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2016-04-25T05:12:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CMEs may impact STEREO A and possibly Spitzer (glancing blow).  The leading edge or flank of the CMEs will reach STEREO A at 2016-04-27T18:07Z and Spitzer at 2016-04-28T16:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME(s): 2016-04-24T23:36:00-CME-001, 2016-04-25T05:12:00-CME-001):
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160425_071000_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160425_071000_2.0_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160425_071000_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160425_071000_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_B.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160425_071000_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160425_071000_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_B.gif

## Notes: 

[1] http://iswawiki.gsfc.nasa.gov/wiki/index.php/Glossary/Heliospheric_Earth_Equatorial_coordinates

S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s

R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2016-04-24T04:24Z.

Estimated speed: ~510 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 40 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -115/24 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates (see [1] in Notes).

Activity ID: 2016-04-24T04:24:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact Spitzer and STEREO A (glancing blow).  The leading edge or flank of the CME will reach Spitzer at 2016-04-27T08:13Z and STEREO A at 2016-04-27T18:00Z (plus minus 7 hours).

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for April 13, 2016 - April 19, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-04-20T21:17:00Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-04-13T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-04-19T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160420-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low to moderate levels during this reporting period with 1 M-class flare (see list below).  There was 1 C-type CME (see details below).   The CME that started on 2016-04-18T00:36Z was associated with the M6.7 class flare that peaked at 2016-04-18T00:29Z (see notification 20160418-AL-001).  Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it was estimated that the CME would have little or no impact on NASA missions near Earth or other locations (see notification 20160418-AL-002).  

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2016-04-13T00:00Z-03:00Z and 2016-04-14T09:00Z-12:00Z.  These slight increases in geomagnetic activity were associated with the arrival detected by ACE at L1 of a coronal hole high speed stream on 2016-04-12 and the weak interplanetary shock detected around 2016-04-14T06:50Z of a CME event that started on 2016-04-10T11:00Z, respectively (see notification 20160412-AL-001).  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES was slightly elevated at the beginning of the reporting period due to the coronal hole high speed steam described above, but remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES was slightly elevated on 2016-04-18 due the M6.7 class flare and its associated CME, but remained under the threshold of 10 pfu for the entire reporting period.  The 13-100 MeV proton flux at STEREO A was at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.


##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
2016-04-18  00:14:00  00:39:00  00:29:00   M6.7   N10W51 ( 12529 ) 


CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2016-04-18T00:36Z     ~689            C                58/9                 37                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-04-20T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-04-26T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  There are a few active regions on the solar disk that can produce some flare and coronal mass ejections activity, specifically an active region on the far side of the Sun that it has been active in the past few days.  Geomagnetic activity could increase with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream by 2016-04-23.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-04-18T03:46:47Z
## Message ID: 20160418-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2016-04-18T00:30Z.

Estimated speed: ~820 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 27 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 54/18 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates (see [1] in Notes).

Activity ID: 2016-04-18T00:30:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CME has little or no impact on NASA missions near Earth or other locations.


Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME(s): 2016-04-18T00:30:00-CME-001):

##

## Message ID: 20160418-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significant flare detected by GOES.

Flare start time: 2016-04-18T00:14Z. 

Flare peak time: 2016-04-18T00:29Z.

Flare intensity: M6.7 class.

Source region: N10W51 (Active Region 12529) (based on SDO imagery).

Increased energetic proton fluxes possible. Updates on this event will be provided when available.

Activity ID: 2016-04-18T00:14:00-FLR-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for April 06, 2016 - April 12, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-04-13T20:01:59Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-04-06T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-04-12T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160413-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were 2 C-type CMEs (see details below).   Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it was estimated that the CMEs starting on 2016-04-10T07:12Z (less than 500 km/s) and 2016-04-10T11:00Z may have a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth at about 2016-04-14T00:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) (see notification 20160412-AL-001).

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2016-04-07T18:00Z to 2016-04-08T03:00Z and 2016-04-12T21:00Z to 2016-04-13T03:00Z.  The increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with coronal hole high speed streams detected by ACE at L1 around 2016-04-08 and 2016-04-12, respectively.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.


##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed 

CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2016-04-10T11:00Z     ~521            C               -24/34                35                          SOHO, STEREO A                    


Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2016-04-07T23:36Z     ~740            C               120/0                 33                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-04-13T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-04-19T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  There are a few active regions on the solar disk, including active region 12529, that are still capable of producing solar flares and coronal mass ejections.  Also, the geomagnetic activity may increase at the beginning of the next reporting period since we are currently under the influence of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 around 2016-04-12.  The solar wind speed has reached values of 698 km/s on 2016-04-13.

O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CMEs (Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-04-12T00:48:31Z
## Message ID: 20160412-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Multiple CMEs have been detected as follows:
1: S-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2016-04-10T07:12Z.

Estimated speed: ~352 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 36 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -53/28 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates (see [1] in Notes).

Activity ID: 2016-04-10T07:12:00-CME-001

2: C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2016-04-10T11:00Z.

Estimated speed: ~521 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 35 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -24/34 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2016-04-10T11:00:00-CME-001

 
Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CMEs may have a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the flank of the CMEs will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2016-04-14T00:00Z (plus minus 7 hours).

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Mars, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-04-07T14:23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160407-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

S-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2016-04-06T16:24Z.

Estimated speed: ~464 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 31 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 14/23 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates (see [1] in Notes).

Activity ID: 2016-04-06T16:24:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect Mars (glancing blow).  The leading edge or flank of the CME will reach Mars around 2016-04-12T00:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may have a slight chance of glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the flank of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2016-04-09T18:00Z (plus minus 7 hours).

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for March 30, 2016 - April 05, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-04-06T16:48:17Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-03-30T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-04-05T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160406-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very low levels during this reporting period.     

Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6 for the reporting period.  Geomagnetic Kp index reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2016-04-02T21:00Z to 2016-04-03T00:00Z. This moderate increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with a coronal hole high speed stream arrival detected by ACE at L1 around 2016-04-02 (see notifications 20160403-AL-001 and 20160403-AL-002).  The highest value of the solar wind speed reached 548 km/s.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period, but were elevated around 2016-04-05 due to the coronal hole high speed stream described above.  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.


##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-04-06T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-04-12T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  There are a few active regions on the solar disk capable of producing solar flares and coronal mass ejections. Especially an active region that is just rotating to the Earth's facing solar disk on the east limb has a potential for additional activity.  The geomagnetic activity may increase around 2016-04-07 due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Geomagnetic Storm
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-04-03T00:51:09Z
## Message ID: 20160403-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Ongoing space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2016-04-02T21:00Z to 2016-04-03T00:00Z. 

The storm is caused by CME with ID 2016-03-31T01:25:00-CME-001 and the ongoing arrival of a corotating interactive region (CIR).

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2016-04-02T22:30:00-GST-001.

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Auto-generated Space Weather Notification - Geomagnetic Storm
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-04-03T00:28:55Z
## Message ID: 20160403-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Ongoing space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2016-04-02T21:00Z to 2016-04-03T00:00Z. 


NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2016-04-02T21:00:00-GST-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for March 23, 2016 - March 29, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-03-31T01:04:04Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-03-23T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-03-29T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160331-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were 1 C-type CME (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period. The Kp reached values of Kp=4 during the synoptic periods of 20016-03-23T06:00Z-09:00Z, 2016-03-28T03:00Z-06:00Z, 2016-03-30T12:00Z-15:00Z.  The slight increase of geomagnetic activity at the end of the reporting period was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 around 2016-03-27.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.


##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2016-03-23T05:00Z     ~503            C                10/23                20                          SOHO, STEREO A                    


Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed   

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-03-30T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-04-05T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  Some active regions present on the solar disk have low magnetic complexity.  However, an active region on the far side has been developing and producing coronal mass ejections.  The geomagnetic activity may become slightly enhanced due to a coronal hole high speed stream expected to arrive around 2016-04-01.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
